body: You should be able to compile gRPC to use OpenSSL instead of BoringSSL. I am not familiar with the build system for iOS however, so I'll let @makdharma or @jcanizales expand on that.

Hi Christian,

the easiest way, although not ideal, would be to copy [`gRPC-Core.podspec`](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/gRPC-Core.podspec) into the repository of your app. Then, in your `Podfile`, add the following line:

``` ruby
pod 'gRPC-Core', :podspec => "." # assuming gRPC-Core.podspec is in the same directory as your Podfile
```

Once you have that, Cocoapods will use your local copy of `gRPC-Core.podspec` instead of the one deployed in Cocoapods' repo. You'll be able to substitute the BoringSSL dependency (in [this line of the podspec](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/cb87dd9fef97d1e1fb2559be68188c0792a3ecd8/gRPC-Core.podspec#L184)) for whatever pod of OpenSSL your other libraries use.

The downside is you'll have to manually copy `gRPC-Core.podspec` again every time there's a new release. But there are ways to make that easier. E.g. if you add the gRPC GitHub repo as a submodule of your app's repo, you won't have to redo your OpenSSL edit every time you update to a new version of gRPC.
Closing due to lack of follow up.
@jcanizales @makdharma It works via modifying Podfile. Thanks;-)
Reopened for https://github.com/firebase/firebase-ios-sdk/issues/1216
Another case: https://github.com/firebase/firebase-ios-sdk/issues/1574
We had a similar problem with the nodejs version of grpc. A quick fix should be to compile boringssl with `-fvisibility=hidden`.
@muxi if you need any help I can work with you to fix this
Thanks. I'll update with any progress.

@bond- thank you! I might not be able to start immediately, but I am thinking of replacing [the boringssl dependency](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/gRPC-Core.podspec#L184) to [openssl](https://cocoapods.org/pods/OpenSSL). Feel free to give it a try and discuss here any issue you encounter.
@muxi There are some references to BoringSSL in the code, not sure if it would break the build.

@muxi: @24601 suggested a similar solution([firebase-ios-sdk/1574](https://github.com/firebase/firebase-ios-sdk/issues/1574)) but was using [GRKOpenSSLFramework](https://cocoapods.org/pods/GRKOpenSSLFramework) which is maintained vs openssl which is not actively maintained.

I don't feel it quite right to depend on some random fork. If there's a common pod that most people use (which I guess is likely the one that openssl.org is maintaining), it's probably a better idea to use that even if it is not actively maintained.

@wilhuff do you have an idea on how people commonly get openssl dependency on iOS? Looks like in firebase/firebase-ios-sdk#1216 they are using prebuilt archives, and in firebase/firebase-ios-sdk#1574 I cannot figure it out.

I can't really tell how the latter got their OpenSSL either. I'm not sure it matters.

Quickly surveying download stats on cocoapods.org [OpenSSL-Universal](https://cocoapods.org/pods/OpenSSL-Universal) is far and away the most popular, followed by [OpenSSL](https://cocoapods.org/pods/OpenSSL). Neither of these have been recently updated.

Unfortunately, switching gRPC's dependency to one of these still wouldn't help someone using Cocos2d-x. There's also a long tail of OpenSSL-related pods in CocoaPods any of which could also conflict. All we can do is make conflict less likely, but making this change isn't going to actually fix the problem.

The best path forward (but overwhelmingly the most work) would be to drop our BoringSSL/OpenSSL requirement altogether on iOS and other Apple platforms and use SecureTransport (or CFSocketStream). These are provided by the OS and designed to be compatible across OS releases. If there's a vulnerability, Apple can ship an update and everyone will be transparently updated without requiring everyone to rebuild.

Another alternative could be to ship a subspec of gRPC that removes the BoringSSL dependency without necessarily providing an alternative. This is difficult in practice because it requires the end user to configure their project such that gRPC can find OpenSSL/BoringSSL headers. It's worth considering though because it's definitely easier than our current workaround which involves cloning and editing the gRPC podspecs. Of course, to make this work for Firestore users, Firestore would need a similar subspec.

@wilhuff and @muxi: I support going the following route and am willing to help too, I must say I am rusty on my C language skills. (FYI, I used Swift for App development)

> The best path forward (but overwhelmingly the most work) would be to drop our BoringSSL/OpenSSL requirement altogether on iOS and other Apple platforms and use SecureTransport (or CFSocketStream). These are provided by the OS and designed to be compatible across iOS releases. If there's a vulnerability, Apple can ship an update and everyone will be transparently updated without requiring everyone to rebuild.

@wilhuff - thank you for the very customer-friendly/user-friendly attitude and discussion. I really appreciate it. If this becomes a work item I will see what resources we may be able to dedicate to a fix as part of our open source commitment.

Thanks @wilhuff. I agree that the best option is to use SecureTransport. We investigated this before when we implemented CFStream. The observation was that SecureTransport does not support ALPN before iOS 11. That drove us away since gRPC is using HTTP/2. That means currently our options are to remove boringssl or to get openssl from somewhere.

Muxi is correct. There is unfortunately an HTTP2 requirement in the SSL
transport layer to handle ALPN, which has been available in OpenSSL /
BoringSSL for a long time now, but is too recent on OS layers, such as iOS
or even Windows.

@muxi Can there be multiple releases. One for pre iOS 11 which removes BoringSSL and one for iOS 11 and above which uses SecureTransport?

Personally, I would be against such complexity demultiplication. There's
only so much we can do to maintain multiple combinations of things, and
adding one more axis in our support matrix is always very costly.

Besides what @nicolasnoble said, iOS 9 and iOS 10 still have a good amount of users and a lot of apps still supporting them. Since Apple Store does not support multiple packages targeting multiple versions, I doubt if app developers are going to use gRPC iOS11+-only release.

@nicolasnoble, @muxi I agree that it's a maintenance nightmare.

The reason I am asking is, if we go the Apple route we would have a permanent fix for the people on iOS 11+. Many other OpenSource projects work that way and also do a end-of-life support at some or the other point.

BTW, I would use iOS11+ release. Count me in as your first user.

> Since Apple Store does not support multiple packages targeting multiple versions

I am not a Pro app developer but I can depend on a specific version of Pod in my Podfile.
As per the report 81% of users are on iOS 11: https://developer.apple.com/support/app-store/

@muxi have you considered compiling boringssl in with ``fvisibility=hidden`` as suggested by @nicolasnoble upthread? This might still not address the bloat of the binary, but can prevent the symbol conflict. Over time, we can switch over to an Apple based solution once the fragmentation reduces.
https://github.com/grpc/grpc-node/pull/241 for the nodejs change we did for the same exact symbol conflict issue in Electron.
I'll give that a try.

@muxi /anyone, Do you have any steps on how to add that flag? I would like to try it locally.

I am guessing do grpc/grpc-node#241 in grpc.gyp??
I'm investigating that too. I tried to add the flag as additional flag to BoringSSL project in Xcode, but that did not seem to work. If you find something let us know.

Given that users primarily want static libraries/frameworks I think this is going to be challenging:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2222162/how-to-apply-gcc-fvisibility-option-to-symbols-in-static-libraries

Hmm that's right. If `-fvisibility` is only enforced by linker, BoringSSL static library will not be affected.

The story is a bit different as I experimented with frameworks. Frameworks are built with linker involved, so `-fvisibility=hidden` indeed forced no-export of BoringSSL functions. But that makes gRPC-Core not finding the BoringSSL symbols since it's a separate framework that depends on BoringSSL.
